Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The collaborative project between the University of Arkansas Little Rock and Indiana University is using Web 2.0 and social networking methods to create an OnLine Chemistry Course (OLCC) in the area of cheminformatics. By leveraging distributed expertise, the project is enabling institutions to educate undergraduate chemists in a skill set that is rapidly increasing in importance to society. In addition to filling a subject gap within the curriculum, the project team is providing an exemplar for a teaching method that can be extended to other areas of undergraduate science education.

The artfully constructed and implemented OLCC is based on prior experience with less demanding offerings. It enables institutions of higher education to teach a class in the emerging area of effective use of computational and informatics techniques as part of the scientific discovery process. Beyond providing state-of-the-art undergraduate educational opportunities at the PIs' institutions, the project is making the cheminformatics materials available to institutions that wish to participate in the hybrid course wherein a facilitator at each participating institution is responsible for the local students grades and assessment. An additional intellectual merit of this sharing of experience is the latent faculty development that occurs as the non-expert facilitators gain experience in the content delivered by the distant experts. Simultaneously, the community is developing experience in and appreciation of new digital learning modalities that are increasingly comfortable to the new generation of 'free-agent learners'.

The OLCC is leading to the development of modules and digital Teaching and Learning Objects that are coded with meta data, retrievable via national and international archival mechanisms, and which can be repurposed and distributed into other curricular environments. The use of experts distributed beyond one campus or one country is educating current students by a new model that makes traditional boundaries of historical interest only. The on-line component of the hybrid course, with its many-lecturer-to-many-student components, coupled with nurtured student-to-student interactions will aid in the building of a diversified community. The OLCC design is developing modern instructional opportunities that extend beyond the traditional classroom and that industrial learners, non-traditional learners, and distance-learners can all utilize in ways that meet their unique needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cheminformatics OLCC is an NSF funded project to generate OER (Open Educational Resource) cheminformatics teaching material targeting the needs of chemistry undergraduate majors, by offering an intercollegiate course in cheminformatics. This project was run under the premise that twenty-first century cheminformatics advances have generated new cognitive artifacts for the representation, manipulation and communication of chemical information, that these artifacts influence the problem-solving schema applied to scientific tasks and can enable new discoveries, and yet the field is noticeably missing from the undergraduate chemistry curriculum, being delegated the role of a niche science of the pharmaceutical/medicinal sciences.

This collaboratively taught hybrid course involved both cheminformaticans within and without academia, who interacted as online lecturers with students from multiple campuses, while working with residential faculty facilitators, the instructors of record, who met face-to-face with students in the classroom. The course was taught on 11 campuses in the Fall of 2015 and the Spring of 2017, the OER material is available on both the course website http://olcc.ccce.divched.org/, and the Libretext hyperlibrary, http://libretexts.org. Material within the hyperlibrary is discoverable in chemistry major’s classes across the curriculum in schools that use the hyperlibrary, facilitating the adoption of cheminformatics content in undergraduate chemistry courses like organic, inorganic and biochemistry.

The term OLCC (OnLine Chemistry Course) is a misnomer dating back to the first OLCC, which was run by the ACS CHED Committee on Computers in Chemical Education in 1996, with the cheminformatics OLCCs being the 6th and 7th OLCCs.  We created our own intercollegiate course management system in Drupal 7 for these courses, where authors posted material online that students discussed through web 2.0 participatory web features. We also created a special web content item called the Teaching and Learning Object (TLO), which had sections that could be embedded into each chapter, allowing the chapters to grow as the class was being taught. That is, it was felt that students could adapt new cheminformatic artifacts to cognitive processes in innovative ways (outside of those established by experts), because experts had already automated many of their cognitive tasks through automation of established schema (that resulted in reduced load), and impeded innovation, while students had no such benefit of prior knowledge. The TLO thus allowed the course management system to capture new content as it was generated by students and faculty as the course proceeded.

One challenge for the integration of cheminformatics into the undergraduate curriculum is that computer programming is not a required competency for chemistry majors, and thus could not be a prerequisite for the course. One innovation that evolved out of this restriction was the “smart spreadsheet”, which allowed non-programmers to webscrape or utilize web services to answer questions. Figure 1. (http://olcc.ccce.divched.org/2017OLCCModule3TLO3) represents a TLO of a spreadsheet that would instantly connect chemical names in a column to information on that chemical at PubChem.  This spreadsheet used IUPAC’s InChI Chemical Identifier, which is effectively 21st century nomenclature, that allows humans, software agents and databases to communicate chemical structural information.  Another TLO is represented in figure 2, which is a spreadsheet that uses a chemical name to webscrape spectral data and an image file from the NIST Chemistry WebBook, for either nmr, IR or UV-Vis spectra, (http://olcc.ccce.divched.org/2017OLCCModule3TLO4) . Each of the above TLO’s has a Youtube and the spreadsheet code used, to allow others to experiment with these techniques, along with a forum for discussion, and both were generated during the class.

Cheminformatics is an expansive topic worthy of many classes, and the course content was narrowed down to a focus on the representation of chemicals on computer, and the use of public compound databases.  The first part clearly supported the traditional undergraduate chemistry curriculum, extending nomenclature to connection tables and line notation, like the layered IUPAC InChI, that forced students to grapple with fundamental concepts like isotopic representation and tautomerization.  The course then built on this material to cover public compound databases, with much of the material being developed by staff scientists at NIH PubChem.  Since the end of the class, two schools have already offered cheminformatics classes using the material, all of which is freely available to be modified at will by other schools, if they wish to integrate it into their curriculum.

The UALR cohort of the Spring 2017 class also integrated the hypothes.is annotation service into their discussions, aggregating in a block at the bottom of each page student annotations of the chapters and the primary literature.  Each entry had a contextual link that opened the page they commented on in a new browser window, scrolled down to their highlighted comment, and showed their annotation in an overlay. This not only allowed students to bring into the discussion the primary literature, but also allowed the instructor to filter through the online discussions and focus on key features during the classroom activities
